abstract: A new form of secured lending utilizing “digital collateral” has recently emerged, most prominently in low and middle income countries. Digital collateral relies on “lockout” technology, which allows the lender to temporarily disable the ﬂow value of the collateral to the borrower without physically repossessing it. We explore this new form of credit both in a model and in a ﬁeld experiment using school-fee loans digitally secured with a solar home system. We ﬁnd that securing a loan with digital collateral drastically reduces default rates (by 19 pp) and increases the lender’s rate of return (by 38 pp). Employing a variant of the Karlan and Zinman (2009) methodology, we decompose the total eﬀect and ﬁnd that roughly one-third is attributable to (ex-ante) adverse selection and two-thirds is attributable to (interim or ex-post) moral hazard. Access to a school-fee loan signiﬁcantly increases school enrollment and school-related expenditures without detrimental eﬀects to households’ balance sheet.
